intro: Colchicum gol-hassrat, commonly known as the Persian meadow saffron, is a bulbous perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of Iran. It belongs to the Colchicaceae family and is characterized by its striking purple to crimson flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant produces a tall scape with a single flower, which consists of six tepals and a central column of stamens. Its bulbs contain colchicine, a toxic alkaloid used in medical treatments. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and botanical collections.
